title: Angular Geometries in H1-H2 Transfer Holography
description: Analyze the angular relationships and spatial origins required for successful H1 to H2 transfer holography.
insight: Proper angular alignment and spatial positioning of the object and reference beams are crucial to ensuring accurate transfer of images between H1 and H2 holograms.
question_text:
In an H1-H2 transfer holography setup:
- H1 is illuminated with a reference beam at an angle of $$\theta_{ref} = 30^\circ$$.
- The object wave converges with a radius of curvature $$R_{obj} = 300 \text{ mm}$$.
- The distance between H1 and H2 is $$d = 200 \text{ mm}$$.

**a)** Calculate the angle of the output beam from H1 required to ensure proper convergence at H2.
**b)** Determine the radius of curvature of the output beam at H2 assuming ideal phase conjugation.

Use the relationship:
$$\theta_{out} = 180^\circ - \theta_{ref}$$
$$R_{out} = R_{obj} + d$$

steps: 1. Use the radius relationship: $$R_{out} = R_{obj} + d$$.
2. Substitute the given values: $$R_{obj} = 300 \text{ mm}$$, $$d = 200 \text{ mm}$$.
The output beam angle is $$150^\circ$$, and the radius of curvature at H2 is $$500 \text{ mm}$$.

title: Color Blur in H2 Hologram Viewing
description: Analyze how color blur arises in an H2 hologram when images from multiple colors recorded in H1 fail to overlap perfectly.
insight: Color blur occurs because different wavelengths reconstruct images at slightly different positions, leading to misalignment of the color components.
question_text:
When viewing an H2 hologram reconstructed from an H1 master, three different wavelengths—$$\lambda_1 = 450 \, nm$$ (blue), $$\lambda_2 = 550 \, nm$$ (green), and $$\lambda_3 = 650 \, nm$$ (red)—form separate images due to their differing reconstruction angles.

The distance between the H1 and H2 plates is $$d = 200 \, mm$$, and the reconstruction angle is approximately $$\theta = 30^\circ$$.

**a)** Calculate the lateral displacement between the red and blue images.
**b)** Discuss why these displacements cause visible color blur in the final image.

Use the relationship for lateral displacement:
$$\Delta x = d \cdot \tan(\theta) \cdot \left(1 - \frac{\lambda_1}{\lambda_3}\right)$$.

steps: 2. Substitute the given values: $$d = 200 \, mm$$, $$\theta = 30^\circ$$, $$\lambda_1 = 450 \, nm$$, $$\lambda_3 = 650 \, nm$$.
1. Each wavelength reconstructs at slightly different angles, leading to spatially displaced images.
2. When the blue, green, and red components do not overlap, the viewer perceives a blurred, rainbow-like effect.
3. This blur is more pronounced at larger viewing angles and greater distances between H1 and H2.
The lateral displacement between red and blue images is approximately $$35.5 \text{ mm}$$, which contributes to visible color blur in the final image.

title: Color Blur in H2 Hologram Projection
description: Analyze how color blur arises in an H2 hologram when images from different wavelengths recorded in H1 reconstruct at varying angles.
insight: Color blur occurs because different wavelengths reconstruct at slightly different angles, causing misalignment of the color images in the H2 plane.
question_text:
In an H1-H2 holographic transfer system, the master hologram (H1) was recorded using three wavelengths: $$\lambda_1 = 480 \, nm$$ (blue), $$\lambda_2 = 580 \, nm$$ (yellow), and $$\lambda_3 = 680 \, nm$$ (red).

The H1 and H2 plates are separated by a distance of $$d = 150 \, mm$$, and the reconstruction angle is $$\theta = 25^\circ$$.

**a)** Calculate the lateral displacement between the blue and red images.
**b)** Explain why these displacements lead to a perceivable blur when viewing the final image.

Use the relationship for lateral displacement:
$$\Delta x = d \cdot \tan(\theta) \cdot \left(1 - \frac{\lambda_1}{\lambda_3}\right)$$.

steps: 2. Substitute the given values: $$d = 150 \, mm$$, $$\theta = 25^\circ$$, $$\lambda_1 = 480 \, nm$$, $$\lambda_3 = 680 \, nm$$.
1. Different wavelengths reconstruct at slightly different angles, causing their corresponding images to appear at slightly different lateral positions on the H2 plate.
2. This misalignment creates a visible blur, especially noticeable in high-contrast or sharp edges in the image.
3. The blur effect becomes more pronounced with larger angular differences and increased separation distances between H1 and H2.
The lateral displacement between the blue and red images is approximately $$20.58 \, mm$$, contributing to observable color blur in the reconstructed image.
